BREAKING Latest climate data shows unprecedented warming trends

Climate change: Global temperatures break records again

By Matt McGrath Environment correspondent 9 January 2024

The year 2023 has been confirmed as the warmest on record, with global temperatures reaching 1.48C above pre-industrial levels, scientists have announced.

Data from multiple international agencies shows that every month from June to December set new temperature records, marking an unprecedented period of global warming.

The findings come as world leaders prepare for crucial climate talks, with scientists warning that the window for limiting warming to 1.5C is rapidly closing.

Record-breaking heat

According to the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S), 2023 surpassed 2016 as the warmest year since records began in 1850. The data shows:

  • Global average temperature was 14.98C, 0.17C higher than 2016
  • Every month from June onwards was the warmest on record
  • September saw the largest temperature anomaly at 0.93C above average

"The extremes we have observed over the last few months provide a dramatic testimony of how far we now are from the climate in which our civilisation developed," said Carlo Buontempo, Director of C3S.

"This has been an extraordinary year for global temperatures. We are now dangerously close to breaching the 1.5C threshold set by the Paris Agreement."

Dr Samantha Burgess, Deputy Director of C3S

Contributing factors

Scientists point to several factors behind the record temperatures:

El Niño: The natural climate pattern returned in 2023, adding to human-caused warming. However, researchers stress that El Niño alone cannot explain the magnitude of temperature increases.

Greenhouse gases: Atmospheric CO2 reached 421 parts per million in 2023, the highest level in over 3 million years.

Ocean temperatures: Sea surface temperatures also broke records, with marine heatwaves affecting over 90% of the ocean at some point during the year.

Global impacts

The record temperatures have been linked to extreme weather events worldwide:

  • Devastating wildfires in Canada, Hawaii, and southern Europe
  • Severe flooding in Libya, Greece, and Brazil
  • Record-breaking heatwaves across Asia, Europe, and North America
  • Accelerated ice loss in Antarctica and Greenland

Looking ahead

Climate scientists warn that without immediate and drastic action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, such extreme years could become the norm rather than the exception.

"We still have a chance to limit warming to 1.5C, but it requires unprecedented action in this decade," said Professor Michael Mann from the University of Pennsylvania.

The findings will add urgency to discussions at the upcoming COP29 climate summit, where nations will review progress on emission reduction commitments.

Analysis

By Matt McGrath, Environment correspondent

These latest figures confirm what many scientists have long feared - that climate change is accelerating faster than predicted. The 1.5C threshold, once seen as a distant target, now appears perilously close.

What's particularly concerning is the rate of change. Just a decade ago, such temperatures would have been considered highly unlikely. Now they're reality.

The question facing world leaders is no longer whether we can prevent warming, but how quickly we can adapt to a rapidly changing world while still trying to limit further temperature rises.

What can be done?

Experts say urgent action is needed across multiple fronts:

  • Renewable energy: Accelerate the transition from fossil fuels
  • Energy efficiency: Improve building standards and transportation
  • Nature-based solutions: Protect and restore forests and wetlands
  • International cooperation: Strengthen climate commitments and financing

The UN Secretary-General António Guterres called the findings "a deafening wake-up call" and urged world leaders to treat climate change as the existential crisis it represents.
